dialogNodes.dialogText:
YOU: "I wanted to ask about your feelings. How are you doing?"

SCHOLAR LEADER: "I am fine, my liege. No causes for concern, I assure you. My thanks for asking."

YOU: "How are things progressing with the tasks you've been assigned? What is your assessment of current production?"

SCHOLAR LEADER: "Things appear to be right on schedule, my liege! About as much as the last few days."

YOU: "I'd like to know your opinion of me, actually. What are your thoughts?"

SCHOLAR LEADER: "I have no complaints as of yet, my liege. I pray my brethren and I may continue our pursuit of knowledge."

YOU: "I was wondering if there was anything I could do to assist you, actually."

SCHOLAR LEADER: "Ah, actually, would you mind trascribing some of those pages over there? That would be most helpful!"

[You nod and take a seat at one of the scholar's messy desks. Picking up a quill and wetting its tip with ink, you proceed to copy over a series of pages of text and diagrams you cannot understand. Regardless, this should allow more scholars to access copies of these surely necessary documents.]

YOU: "How are things between you and the Merchants?"

SCHOLAR LEADER: "Silver-tongued devils, but I'll admit they have a knack for acquire rare tomes and artifacts. I suppose we could learn a thing or two from the way they handle business..."

YOU: "What are your thoughts on the soldiers?"

SCHOLAR LEADER: "They keep us safe. Do I have any right to complain? I would think not! Though, it worries me somewhat that my life lies in the hands of a stranger. P-Perhaps I should pay the sergeant a visit..."

YOU: "How is your relationship with the smithies?"

SCHOLAR LEADER: "Their work-ethic and ability to transform our research into tangible products never ceases to amaze me. I hardly know what we'd do without them! Inspiring, to say the least."

YOU: "How do you feel about the farmers?"

SCHOLAR LEADER: "Earnest and hard-working folk. I do admit, I might not have the constitution to work the fields day-in and day-out, but I prefer the power of the mind. Hm... I suppose I could use some exercise..."

YOU: "I need you and your subordinates to work a little harder. The more discoveries we make, the more advanced our society will be."

SCHOLAR LEADER: "Brain-work takes time, my liege. But, I'll see what can be done."

YOU: "You and your subordinates may work less, should you need the rest. Can't have you burned out when we need your discoveries the most."

SCHOLAR LEADER: "Really? I'll let everyone know. I'm sure they'll be glad to get a little more sleep. Thank you, my liege."

YOU: "What am I paying you cretins for?! I need to see results! Bring me something new or I'll have the guards bring me your head!"

[The scholar leader quivers in fear before you, defensively holding a book to their chest. Your personal bodyguard, a knight in full-plate, casts the frightened researcher an evil grin. They nearly faint.]

YOU: "What do you think of our city? I'd like to know your thoughts."

SCHOLAR LEADER: "It's our home, my liege. I love it. I think everyone else would say the same."

YOU: "I've noticed a dip in production. Are you not pulling your weight?"

[The head researcher fidgets.]

SCHOLAR LEADER: "O-of course I am, my liege! I don't know what you're talking about!"

YOU: "Did you think I would not notice the decline in your production? I will not tolerate corruption! Reveal your treachery!"

[The head researcher furrows their brow and speaks loudly and indignantly.]

SCHOLAR LEADER: "My liege! How dare you accuse me of such a thing! I would never betray you!"

YOU: "It would appear that production is slipped below acceptable levels. Tell me, is everything alright?"

[The head researcher takes a deep breath, exhaling slowly before responding.]

SCHOLAR LEADER: "...I'll be fine, my liege. Thank you for your inquiry."

[You intimidate your subordinate into entertaining your presence for a little longer. 

As you cast off an ominous presence and giving warning looks, the leader of the scholars appear to be a little fearful of what you may do...]

[You politely posture yourself, understanding of your subordinate's undoubtedly busy schedule. 

The head scholar appears to notice this and in recognition of your thoughtfulness, they relax their stance and smile. It would appear that they've decided to entertain your presence a little longer. Politness has its perks!]

[Using your natural charm, your subordinate's attention is re-affixed to your person. 

The leader of the scholars shifts somewhat uncomfortably as their gaze becomes glued to your body. They try to shake off the miasma of passion surrounding you, but it just doesn't seem to work. Entirely distracted by your powers of seduction, they won't be asking you to leave anytime soon...]
